questions.question: What is the most common type of multifetal pregnancy?
What is the time of division of the inner cell mass in a diamniotic monochorionic pregnancy?
questions.explanation: Diamniotic monochorionic pregnancy occurs if the division of inner cell mass takes place between4th - 8th day after fertilization.The timing of the division of zygote for each type of twinning is given below.Monozygotic twin typesDichorionic diamnioticTime of zygote division<72 hoursMonochorionic diamniotic (more common)Monochorionic monoamniotiC3144-8 days8-12 daysMonozygotic twin typesConjoined twinsTime of zygote division>12 days

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding multifetal pregnancies?

options.A: Number of embryos implanted affects the risk of twinning
options.B: Isograft is done between monozygotic twins
options.C: Twins of opposite sex are usually dizygotic
options.D: Same sex twins having same blood group are always monozygotic

questions.explanation: Same sex twins of the same blood group are not always monozygotic but can also be dizygotictwins as well. The genetic relationship between dizygotic twins is the same as any siblings.Option A: More the number of embryos transferred in IVF, more is the risk of twinning. Hence,single embryo transfer is being recommended by the American Society for Reproductive Medicine(2017) to prevent twin gestation.Option B: Isograft is done between monozygotic twins as they have HLA homology.Option C: Twins of the opposite sex are usually dizygotic. Rarely, somatic mutations orchromosomal aberrations can change the sex of 1 or both of the monozygotic twins.

questions.question: The examination findings of a pregnant woman are suggestive of her having conjoined twins.Which is the most common type of such twins?
questions.explanation: Thoracopagus is the most common type of conjoined twins.Division of the inner cell mass after the 12th day of fertilization results in the development ofconjoined or Siamese twins. Based on the parts of the body joined, they are of the following types:•• Ventral• Rostral• Omphalopagus (abdomen)•Thoracopagus (upper chest)• Cephalopagus (head)• Caudal•Ischiopagus (conjoined spines at 180 angle)• Lateral•• Paraphagus (side by side fusion with a shared pelvis)• Dorsal•Craniopagus (skull)•Rachipagus (vertebral arches)•Pyopagus (pelvis)Sharing of organs is common among conjoined twins. MRI imaging is done later in pregnancy forthe evaluation of organ sharing between conjoined twins who are being planned for surgicalseparation.315Conjoined twinsROThoracopagusParapagus* MCraniopagusMARROWPygopagus

questions.question: Which of the following can be used to calculate the incidence of multifetal gestation?
questions.explanation: The incidence of multiple pregnancies is calculated by Hellin's rule.According to this rule, incidence= 1 : 80(n-1), where n is the number of fetuses.Factors affecting the incidence of twin pregnancies are:• Monozygotic• ART•Dizygotic•• Race• Heredity• Maternal age•Parity•Family history of twinning• Good nutritional status• Infertility therapyOption A: Tei index or myocardial performance index (MPI) is calculated using ventriculardoppler imaging. It is used to assess cardiac function in TTTS.Option C: CHOP score is used for cardiac evaluation of recipient twin in TTTS.Option D: Kleihauer-Betke test is used to evaluate the approximate volume of fetomaternalhemorrhage in cases of Rh-D alloimmunization.316

questions.question: In which of the following instances is there an increased chance of twinning?
questions.explanation: Increasing maternal age, family history of twinning, and conception after stopping OCPs increasethe risk of twinning.Taller, well-built women have an increased risk of twinning compared to shorter undernourishedwomen. IVF increases the risk of twinning but single embryo transfer reduces the risk ofmultifetal pregnancies.Factors affecting the incidence of twin pregnancies:•Monozygotic•• ART• Dizygotic•Race• Heredity• Maternal age•Parity• Family history of twinning• Good nutritional status•Infertility therapyNote- A family history of twinning (maternal and paternal) causes an increased chance oftwinning. It is seen that maternal history of twinning has a higher chance of twinning ascompared to a paternal history of twinning.

questions.question: In superfecundation, which of the following is seen?

options.A: Fertilisation of 2 ova released at the same time by sperms released at single intercourse
options.B: Fertilisation of 2 ova released in the same cycle by sperms released at intercourse on 2 differentoccasion

questions.explanation: Superfecundation is the fertilization of two different ova released in the same cycle, bytwo separate acts of coitus within a short period of time.Superfecundation is the fertilization of two different ova in the same menstrual cycle (assuggested by the same gestational age) by separate acts of coitus. It can occur even after artificialreproductive therapy. Hence, after embryo transfer, intercourse must be avoided. Heteropaternalsuperfecundation is used to refer to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins.This leads to the possibility of twins also being half-siblings. This may give rise to the doubt ofadultery and infidelity.Superfetation is the fertilization of two ova released in different menstrual cycles. This is not seenin humans. The nidation and development of one fetus over another fetus is theoretically possibleuntil the decidual space is obliterated by 14-16 weeks of pregnancy.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition given in the image?305

options.A: It is more common in monochorionic pregnancies
options.B: It cannot be detected by sonography
options.C: It is diagnosed usually after delivery
options.D: Morbidity in the co-twin is due to hypotension

questions.explanation: 317The above image shows fetus compressus which appears as a tan ovoid mass compressed againstthe fetal membranes. It can be detected early by sonography.In multifetal pregnancies, if one of the fetuses dies early in pregnancy, the surviving fetuscontinues to develop normally. It can lead to the following outcomes:Factors affecting the prognosis of the surviving twin:• Gestational age at fetal death: 2nd and 3rd trimester deaths increase the risk of morbidity in thesurviving twin• Chorionicity: Monochorionic twins with early fetal death have an increased risk of morbidity inthe surviving twin. This is due to neurological abnormality and vascular anastomoses.⚫ Duration between fetal demise and delivery of surviving twin•Surviving twin may be born preterm leading to an increased risk of fetal demiseDeath in the surviving twin occurs mostly due to vascular anastomoses between the twins. Thesurviving twin can develop sudden hypotension due to these anatomoses after fetal demise.OutcomeDisappearsTypeVanishing twinGets compressedFlattened through desiccationFetus compressusFetus papyraceus

questions.question: A woman is diagnosed to have twins during her dating scan. What is the most commonpresentation in such pregnancies?
questions.explanation: The most common presentation in twins is both vertex/cephalo-cephalic presentation (60%). Theother presentations include:•Cephalo-Breech (20%)•Breech-Cephalic (10%)•• Breech-Breech (6-10%)• Transverse-Transverse (Rarest)Mode of delivery depends on the presentation of the 1st twin as:Presentation of the 1st twinMode of deliveryVertexVaginalBreechCaesarean sectiTransverseonCaesarean section318

questions.question: The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is:
questions.explanation: The best time to identify the type of twin pregnancy on ultrasound is 11-14 weeks.Twin pregnancies should ideally be dated when the crown-rump length (CRL) measurement isbetween 45 and 84 mm (i.e. 11 + 0 to 13 + 6 weeks of gestation).Chorionicity should be ideally determined between 11 +0 and 13 + 6 weeks of gestation (theearliest time to identify chorionicity is 7 weeks). This is done using the membrane thickness at thesite of insertion of the amniotic membrane into the placenta. The T■sign (in monochorionictwins) or lambda sign (in dichorionic twins) can be seen here. As the determination of chorionicityis most accurate when the amnion and chorion have not yet been fused, the first trimester scanin twin pregnancy is highly important.Markers of dichorionicity include 4 layers of membranes between the twins, membrane thickness>2mm, different sex of twins, 2 different placentas, and positive twin peak sign.Women with an uncomplicated dichorionic twin pregnancy should have a first trimester scan, adetailed second trimester scan, and scans every 4 weeks thereafter.Women with uncomplicated monochorionic twins should have a first trimester scan and thenscans every 2 weeks from 16 weeks onwards. This is done in order to detect TTTS and TAPS in atimely manner.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman conceived after being treated for infertility. Her USG scan is givenbelow. What is her diagnosis?BFGG58%TEI D 10 cmPRC 13-3-HPST 3XVPRSRUM3OBS 3.TM CA1421
questions.explanation: The given image shows the twin peak sign which is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twins. This isalso known as the lambda sign or delta sign.In dichorionic twins, the intervening membrane between the twins has 4 layers i.e. 2 chorions and2 amnions. The placenta protrudes from the base to the space between the 2 amnion layers. Thisgives rise to the twin peak sign i.e. triangle with the base at placenta and apex in the interveningmembrane.319USG findings in Twin PregnancyAmnionARROWChorionMonochorionic diamniotic twins - T signMARROWDichorionic diamniotic twins - Twin peak signMARROWSonographic assessment of dichorionicity is done by observing the following:• Number of placental masses - 2• Presence of intervening membrane - twin peak or lambda or delta signThickness of intervening membranes ≥ 2mmThe best time of delivery of dichorionic diamniotic twins is 38 weeks.

questions.question: A primigravida presents to the ANC clinic for the first time at 14 weeks of gestation. Shecomplains of excessive nausea and vomiting. On examination, fundal height is midwaybetween pubic symphysis and umbilicus. The T sign in seen on USG. What is her diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the T sign seen on USG points towards a diagnosisof monochorionic diamniotic twins.The T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. In monochorionicdiamniotic twins, the separating membrane is made up only by the two amniotic membranes withno intervening chorion. This can be seen in the latter part of the first trimester or the beginning ofthe second trimester.Symptoms of multifetal pregnancy:• Increased nausea and vomiting in early months• Palpitations and shortness of breath.•Increased swelling of legs, varicose veins and haemorrhoids• Unusual rate of uterine growth• Excessive fetal movementsSigns of multifetal pregnancy:• Increased weight gain• Hypertension320• Barrel shaped abdomen• Increased fundal height and abdominal girth•Multiple fetal parts•Palpation of 2 fetal heads• FHS at different spots with FHR difference of at least 10bpmMonochorionic diamniotic pregnancy is terminated between 34-37 weeks+6 days.The below image shows the T sign.TEI D 10PRC 13-3-HPST 3XV CPRS 3DBS 3.TM CA1421

questions.question: Which of the following images depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy?307
questions.explanation: The USG in image 2 depicts monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy. It is identified by the T sign.In monochorionic diamniotic twins, the intervening membrane has only 2 layers (i.e) 2 amnions.This thin membrane is seen ending at the common placenta giving rise to the T sign.321USG findings in Twin PregnancyAmnionARROWChorionMonochorionic diamniotic twins - T signMARROWDichorionic diamniotic twins - Twin peak signOMARROWSonographic assessment of monochorionicity is done by observing the following:• Single placental mass• Presence of intervening membrane - T sign• Thin intervening membrane <2mmThe best time of delivery of monochorionic diamniotic twins is 34-37weeks + 6 days.Image 1: Dichorionic twins with twin peak or lambda signImage 3: Monochorionic monoamniotic twins with no intervening membranes between themImage 4: Triplets with 3 separate gestational sacs

questions.question: A mother with twin pregnancy underwent routine USG. Estimated fetal weights werecalculated for both twins. What is the criteria to diagnose pathological discordant growth inthis pregnancy?

options.A: Difference of >25% with larger twin as index
options.B: Difference of <50% with larger twin as index
options.C: Difference of >50% with smaller twin as index
options.D: Difference of >20% with larger twin as index

questions.explanation: A difference in estimated fetal weight of >20% with larger twin as index is one of the criteriafor diagnosing discordant growth.Discordant growth is the unequal size/ weight among the fetuses in a multifetal gestation. It canbe diagnosed by either of the following:• Estimated fetal weight difference > 20%• Discordance = (weight of larger twin - weight of smaller twin/weight of larger twin) x 100Discordant growth in monochorionic twins is due to placental vascular anastomoses. Indichorionic twins, it occurs due to differences in genetic growth potential and suboptimalimplantation site for one of the fetuses.

questions.question: In a woman receiving artificial reproductive therapy, the inner cell mass divides on the 7thday. Which of the following complications is not seen in the resulting multifetal pregnancy?
questions.explanation: 322The division of the inner cell mass on the 7th day will result in monochorionic diamniotic type oftwin pregnancy. Cord entanglement is seen in monoamniotic twins and not in diamniotic twins.The timing of the division of zygote for each type of twinning is given below.Complications in monochorionic diamniotic twins occur due to placental vascular anastomoses.They include:•Twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)•⚫ Twin reversed arterial perfusion (TRAP) or acardiac twin•Twin anaemia polycythemia syndrome (TAPS)Monochorionic monoamniotic twins have a high fetal death rate. This is due to the followingcomplications:• Preterm birth• Congenital anomalies• Low birth weight• Cord entanglementMonozygotic typesTime of zygote divisionDichorionic diamniotic<72 hoursMonochorionic diamniotic (more common)4-8 daysMonochorionic monoamnioti8-12 daysCConjoined twins>12 days

questions.question: What is the most common type of placental vascular anastomoses seen in monochorionictwin pregnancies?
questions.explanation: Artery-vein anastomoses are most commonly seen in monochorionic pregnancies.All monochorionic placentas have anastomoses that can be:•Superficial artery-vein• Deep artery-vein•Artery-artery• Vein-vein• One vessel with connections to multiple arteries and veinsThese anastomoses are not functional as long as the fetuses are hemodynamically balanced. Whena pressure gradient develops between the fetuses, complications can occur like:⚫ TTTS - Twin-twin transfusion syndrome•• TAPS - Twin anemia polycythemia sequence323• TRAP - Twin reversed arterial perfusionThe most common complication in monochorionic twins is twin-twin transfusion syndrome(TTTS). Deep artery-vein anastomosis is the pathology seen in this condition.

questions.question: A 26-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, is diagnosed to have twin-twin transfusionsyndrome. Which of the following statements is true regarding the recipient twin in thiscondition?

options.B: It is called the stuck twin

questions.explanation: Congestive heart failure is seen in the recipient twin.Twin-twin transfusion syndrome is a deep arteriovenous anastomotic complication seenin monochorionic diamniotic twins. Deoxygenated blood from the donor enters through theanastomosis into a shared cotyledon for oxygen exchange. Oxygenated blood is taken up by therecipient twin causing imbalance in the blood volumes.Diagnosis of TTTS depends on 2 USG criteria:• Monochorionic diamniotic gestation• Hydramnios (DVP>8cm) in one twin and oligohydramnios (DVP<2cm) in the other twinTreatment modalities for TTTS:• Serial amnioreduction• Laser ablation of vascular placental anastomoses• Selective fetal terminationNote: Donor twin is called the stuck twin as the oligohydramnios limits fetal movement.Donor twin characteristicsOliguriaOligohydramniosHypotensionAnaemiaActivation of renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS)Renal failure, growth restriction, pulmonary hypoplasia, contracturesRecipient twin characteristicsPolyuriaPolyhydramniosHypertensionPolycythemiaActivation of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)Congestive cardiac failure, premature rupture of membranes

questions.question: The ultrasound findings in a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy are indicative ofpoly-oli syndrome. What is the pathology seen in this condition?
questions.explanation: In poly - oli or polyhydramnios - oligohydramnios syndrome, the basic pathology is the presenceof a deep artery-vein anastomosis.TTTS can present as poly-oli syndrome or twin oligohydramnios polyhydramnios syndrome(TOPS). This is usually seen in mid-pregnancy. In this syndrome, there is decreased donor renalperfusion, causing oliguria and oligohydramnios. Because of the anastomosis, the recipient twin324has increased renal perfusion and increased urine production causing polyhydramnios.Donor twin characteristics Recipient twin characteristicsOliguriaOligohydramniosPolyuriaPolyhydramniosHypotensionAnemiaRenal failureGrowth restrictionPulmonary hypoplasiaContracturesHypertensionPolycythemiaCongestive cardiac failurePremature rupture of membranesHyperbilirubinemia

questions.question: Ultrasound findings in a twin pregnancy are given below:
questions.explanation: The given USG findings are indicative of twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) with twin Abeing the recipient and twin B being the donor twin. Oligohydramnios (AFI<5cm), absent urineand abnormal Doppler flow findings in the donor twin indicate stage III of twin-twin transfusionsyndrome according to Quintero staging.Quintero staging system for TTTS classification:StagUSG findingsIDiscordant amniotic fluid volumes + urine visible in donor's bladderIIDiscordant amniotic fluid volumes + urine not visible in donor's bladderIIIStage II + abnormal Dopplerstudies of umbilical artery/vein or ductus venosusIVAscites or frank hydrops in either twinVDeath of either twin

questions.question: An anxious mother pregnant with twins was recently diagnosed with twin-twin transfusionsyndrome. She wants to know the possible fetal outcome of the pregnancy. Which of thefollowing investigations can be used to predict this?
questions.explanation: In twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), the fetal outcome depends on the cardiac function ofthe recipient twin. Tei index or myocardial performance index (MPI) is used to assess the325ventricular function using doppler.Option A: Deepest vertical pocket on USG is used to diagnose polyhydramnios-oligohydramnios inTTTS.Options B and D: Fetal haemoglobin and MCA peak systolic velocity are used to diagnose TAPS(Twin anaemia polycythemia syndrome).

questions.question: What is/are the placental vascular abnormality that can be seen in the condition depicted inthe image given below?
questions.explanation: The given image shows an acardius acephalus fetus. This refers to the acardiac twin seen in twinreversed arterial perfusion (TRAP). Both artery-artery and vein-vein anastomosis can be seen inTRAP.TRAP is a placental vascular anastomotic complication seen in monochorionic twins. In thisdisorder, deoxygenated blood from the donor twin enters the recipient twin through theanastomosis and supplies the lower half of the recipient's body. Hence, the heart and upper bodyof the recipient is poorly developed.The below image depicts the circulation pattern seen in TRAP.Based on the supply of deoxygenated blood, the recipient twin might have the following fates:The donor twin develops high output cardiac failure.The treatment for this condition is radiofrequency ablation of the acardiac or recipient twin.FateTypeLower body is perfused with f Acardius acephalusailed head growthPartially developed head withAcardius myelecephalidentifiable limbsus326FateTypeNo recognizable structureAcardius amorphous

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman, pregnant with twins, goes into labour. Following the vaginal delivery ofthe first twin, she was taken to the OT for internal version. What could have been the possibleindication for this procedure?
questions.explanation: The second twin being in transverse lie is the only indication for internal version in modernobstetrics.In a twin pregnancy, if the first twin has vertex presentation, vaginal delivery can be performed.Following the vaginal delivery of the first twin, if the second twin is in transverse lie, it iscorrected by external version (preferably cephalic) into a longitudinal lie. If external version failsand the membranes are intact, internal version is done under general anaesthesia, followed bybreech extraction.If the membranes are ruptured, caesarean section is done immediately.Mode of delivery depends on the presentation of the 1st twin:Presentation of the 1st twinMode of deliveryVertexBreechVaginalCaesarean sectionTransverseCaesarean section

questions.question: Identify this condition.
questions.explanation: The given specimen depicts a monochorionic monoamniotic pregnancy as:• 2 umbilical cords are arising from 1 placenta (monochorionic)• No intervening amniotic membrane is attached to the placenta. This means that both fetusesmust have been inside a single amniotic cavity (monoamniotic).Option B: In Monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy, on gross examination, there will be 1 placentaand intervening 2 layers of amnion attached to the placenta. In this type of pregnancy, each fetuswill have its own amniotic cavity (diamniotic) with a shared placenta (monochorionic). This isseen if the fertilized zygote divides into 2 between 4-8 days.The below given gross image of monochorionic diamniotic pregnancy shows two umbilical cordsarising separately from the placenta with the intervening amniotic membrane held by the forceps.327Option D: In dichorionic diamniotic pregnancy each fetus has it's own amnion & chorion.The placentas here may be fused or separate. This is seen in dizygotic twins as well asmonozygotic twins that divide within 0-4 days.Option A: Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) most commonly complicatesmonochorionic (single placenta) twin pregnancy. In TTTS blood is transfused from the donor twinto the recipient twin through the abnormal vascular connections within the placenta leaving thedonor anemic while the recipient becomes polycythemic.The box below describes the type of amnion and chorion seen in different types of twinsdepending on the time of division.Dizygotic twinsMonozygotic twins- division.occurs withino-4 days4-8 days8-12 days>13 daysDichorionic diamnioticDichorionic diamnioticMonochorionic diamnioticMonochorionic monoamnioticMonochorionic monoamniotic conjoined twins328

questions.question: cm23311A pregnant woman was diagnosed with triplets on ultrasound. The obstetrician has plannedto do a selective fetal reduction of one of the fetuses to improve the outcome of thepregnancy. What is the ideal timing and the method for the procedure?
questions.explanation: Selective fetal reduction is done between 10-13 weeks via intracardiac injection of KCl.In multi-chorionic multifetal gestations, selective reduction of the smallest or anomalousfetus/fetuses is done to increase the chance of survival of the other fetuses.Laser ablation or bipolar coagulation of the umbilical cord of the targeted fetus is done. Thisprotects the surviving fetuses from the adverse effects of the drug.

questions.question: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for anantenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she waspregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breechposition and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on twooccasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next?

options.A: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
options.C: Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.explanation: Immediate cesarean section is done as the first twin is in breech presentation. Uncomplicateddichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies are terminated at 38 weeks of gestation.Timing of delivery depends on the type of twin pregnancy:The mode of delivery depends on the 1st twin:After delivery of 1st twin, if the 2nd twin is in breech, assisted breech delivery is done. If the 2ndtwin is in a transverse lie, the internal podalic version is done under GA in the OT followed bybreech extraction.Complications in attempting vaginal delivery in non-vertex presentation (i.e) transverse andbreech:• Interlocking of twins• Fetal head trapping above the cervix• Umbilical cord prolapse329According to ACOG criteria (2019), preeclampsia requires proteinuria of grade 2+ or more. In thecase of pre-eclampsia, termination of pregnancy must be done at 37 weeks. According to theupdated criteria, this patient does not have pre-eclampsia. Hence, a Caesarean section can bedone at 38 weeks as for any uncomplicated DCDA twin pregnancy.Type of twin pregnancyDichorionic diamnioticMonochorionic diamnioticMonochorionic monoamnioticTiming of delivery38 weeks3437 weeks + 6 days32 34 weeks by Caesarean section1st twin presentatioMode of delivenVertexBreechryVaginalCesarean sectionTransverseCesarean section

questions.question: A 26-year-old primigravida with dichorionic diamniotic twins presents to the clinic in activelabor. The first twin is delivered vaginally but the second has a transverse lie. A trial of ECVwas unsuccessful. What is not a complication of the procedure performed next for thedelivery of the second twin?
questions.explanation: The given clinical procedure is suggestive of internal podalic version for the second twin. Shoulderpresentation, and not face presentation, is a complication of this procedure.The complications seen with internal podalic version are as follows:• Maternal-••Failure of the procedure• Uterine rupture•.· Vaginal and perineal trauma• Placental abruption• Postpartum haemorrhage• Ascending infection• Anaesthetic risks• Fetal-••Cord prolapse• Shoulder presentation with prolapsed arm• Skeletal injury (femur, hips, humerus, skull)Visceral injury (kidney, liver, spleen)330••Neural injury (facial nerve)Hypoxic brain injury• Death331
